DOC.brief_summary: The purpose study determine whether Interleukin-2 dose schedule use study help increase tumor shrinkage .
DOC.detailed_description: In phase II study , IL-2 schedule ( daily IL-2 5 day ( per week ) every 3 week ) test cohort kidney cancer patient attempt determine response rate , median duration response , median survival . The dose intensity schedule would allow patient treat regimen achieve target threshold ( > 1440 million IU/m2/year ) .
DOC.criteria: 1 . Patients must histologic diagnosis metastatic kidney cancer . Patients may receive prior systemic therapy may previously untreated 2 . Patients must bidimensional measurable disease physical exam radiologic study . 3 . ECOG performance status 0 1 estimate survival least 3 month . 4 . White blood count > 3500/mm3 , platelet count > 100,000/mm3 , hemoglobin > 9.0 gm/dl ; bilirubin , ALT , AST < 3 x upper limit normal ; serum creatinine < 2.0 mg/dl . 5 . Patients must undergo lowlevel cardiac stress test screen possible atherosclerotic heart disease . Patients positive stress test would exclude trial . 6 . Patients elevate temperature > 100.5 F must source occult infection exclude . 7 . Patients must felt recovered effect prior therapy , > 2 week prior chemotherapy . 8 . Patient consent must obtain prior entrance onto study . 9 . Women childbearing potential must negative pregnancy test must take adequate precaution prevent pregnancy treatment 1 . Medical illness require corticosteroid immunosuppressive agent ( cyclosporin methotrexate . 2 . Autoimmune disease inflammatory arthritis could exacerbate immunebased therapy . 3 . Prior history psychiatric disorder could exacerbate interleukin2 . 4 . Lactation pregnancy . 5 . Evidence significant cardiovascular disease include history recent ( < 6 month prior ) myocardial infarction , congestive heart failure , primary cardiac arrhythmia ( due electrolyte disorder drug toxicity , example ) beyond occasional PVC 's , angina , positive lowlevel stress test , cerebrovascular accident . 6 . Current brain metastasis .
